title: Very simple solution to "people dont want to play two roles"
body:
Why dont they just add a check box for the second role that is "no second role" and when they select that a message pops up saying, in effect, because you've selected a single role your matchmaking times may be slower. 

If someone is so committed to a single role, then they should be willing to wait an extra 30s-1m to play it.

replies.body:
No, because this increases queue times on a server widescale. The whole reason Riot made two picks mandatory is to reduce queue times to an acceptable level. Combinatorics scale MASSIVELY quickly. forcing two roles does not increase your queue time by 30-60 seconds unless your average queue time to begin with was near instantaneous for ALL roles.

Allowing only one selection most likely increased average wait time to between 20 and 30 minutes per queue.
So why did teambuilder work? Everyone only picked one role, should have taken hours to find a game right?

I hypothesize for a few reasons:

1. Dynamic skill lvl bias - your skill at champion and at a role was factored into teambuilder. This allows someone in bronze to be fairly matched with someone in Diamond in theory. This increases the pool of players you can fairly be matched against, which reduces queue time
2. Teambuilder had huge pool to begin with - Blind pick has the most players in it at any given time. Team builder actually had more than draft. Despite the fact that there are roughly 12 million accounts (and I think 700k players on in a server at any given moment on average), ranked has a ridiculously small population as opposed to the other queues. Quartering a population size doesn't necessarily reduce the number of potential valdi combinations by 75%; combinatorics just doesn't work that way. So population size has non-linear effects on queue times.
3. And it kind of did - it did not take literal hours, but if you wanted to start a game from scratch, it was several minutes for a team + matching. It felt longer because it was active waiting, but time from creation to actual game start was roughly equivalent to Blind. But that's not what we think of when we refer to "queue times." We think of the average time between queueing up and pressing accept. That has always been significantly longer in ranked than even just normal draft, especially at higher mmr

Because, from my understanding, it's a compounding issue. If you alone only picked 1 lane/role then the impact would be inconsequential, but by allowing players to pick only 1 if they so desired there would be a high imbalance of roles.

I'll call that a steaming pile of bovine excrements.

First of all both normal queues and ranked queues have their own MMR for each player.
Secondly, both blind pick and draft pick have their own separate MMR.
Thirdly, every map has it's own separate MMR. (which is irrelevant here, but I thought you'd want to know)

Now to the main event.

Not only Teambuilder had it's very own separate MMR, it also accounted for each and every single **individual champion** you played **separately**. Moreso, it was also giving you "leg-up" for your first few games.

Of course the system can widen the ELO range for matchmaking purposes, but **ONLY** within the same queue.

Should there be a situation where there is only one person in solo ranked Plat and it's Plat 3 on the server they could be matched with Diamond or Gold from solo ranked, but ONLY from solo ranked.

It will never use team ranked or normal MMR to find player.
**NEVER**.

Actually, no, the timing of matchmaking would be more hindered by multiple team roles. The absolute fastest matchmaking would occur with a player scoring system (like mmr) and a single role. Why? Because the players could then be placed into a queue by rank/rating, and rapidly combined with a standardized team composition according to that rank (or rank range even). You can simulate this by using a deck of poker cards. Separate the cards by suit. The card values equate to a player rank/rating. Line up the cards by value and line up the suits. You can scoop all the cards of the same value in each suit in one motion.

Come up with a deck of cards that has roughly 3k suits and perform the same algorithm. It's significantly harder. While it's useful to perform algorithms on small systems to see if it works at all, large systems behave differently than small systems. Thus, you have to test it on sufficiently large systems, not small ones.

Do also keep in mind that there can be as much as a 100 mmr spread within a single tier of a division, which is enough to skew what could be naively said as a fair match to have as much as 3:2 odds. And with every mmr you shave off to make the variation smaller in skill, you make the population smaller, which can disproportionately affect queue times. One of Riot's challenges is to balance queue times with consistency in game experience. Even though it's unlikely, waiting 20 minutes for a game where you expect 99.7% of the games to be even matched is fine, but if you think that the game was a stomp (whether it really was or not), waiting so long only to get a shitty game is probably going to make you quit.

Let's not get started about trolls ruining games either. While Riot doesn't condone trolls at all, building a queue system without taking into account the potential for assholes is stupid.

To verify; I just spent five minutes writing a short program that creates one hundred million players with an id number. It assigns a random rating and two random roles to each. It puts each player into a queue by those roles. It creates ten million matches, which was a class object. It finishes that in less than two seconds. Let's not make it sound more complex than it is.

Saying you've done something isn't verification. What you have done is created a matrix that has 10^8 rows and 4 columns and then found 10^7 combinations of 10 1x4 vectors from that matrix. That is computationally intense depending on what language you use and your processor, but not difficult.

What matters is that the matching is within a winrate tolerance for an acceptable proportion of the population.

But for the record, I booted up R to see how long it would take to generate a string that was 10^8 long. Granted, R does not have the best for-loop efficiency, but it's passable. It took roughly 20 seconds on my i7 to generate only 10^6. So my estimation is that simply generating the 100 million IDs for each player would take about 5 and a half hours.

here's my R code if you're interested:
row=c()

for (i in 1:10^6){
	row=c(row,i)
}

So bottom line, I'm fairly confident that you're at the very least vastly under-exaggerating on the internet to try to win an argument.

It will massively increase queue time, in long term. I introduce you Schelling segregation.

Step 1: People who want to play 1 role queue only 1 role. Queue time increases slightly (1-2 mins)
Step 2: People realizes it takes less effort to move up the ladder if they play just one role, at the expense of slight increase in queue time (2-3 mins)
Step 3: Everyone who enjoys one role slightly less than the other will eventually make the switch, and play only one role. They will enjoy their other role in blindpick. Queue time increases significantly (5-10 mins)
Step 4: Everyone tells their friends and mother that playing only one role is 'the right way' to play ranked. Queue time increases significantly (10-15 mins)
Step 5: We have a new generation of players who refuse to play more than one role. 
Step 6: Server-wide 20-30 min queue time on average.
